pred: \boxed{At close-up view, the Black Kite’s nostril on the bill is oval/elliptical in shape.}
\boxed{The sepals of Mexican star (Milla biflora) are arranged alternately with the petals, lying between them on the back side of the corolla.}

\boxed{No. The ventral side (belly) of the Red Salamander has black spots, but the *back* (dorsal side) is where the more obvious black spots appear. The ventral abdomen is typically lighter and less boldly spotted than the back, so it does not display the same prominent black dot pattern as the dorsal surface.}

\boxed{No. The tail (posterior) section of the abdomen of the Carolina Metallic Tiger Beetle is dark (typically blackish or brownish) and does not share the light yellowish coloration that appears along the outer edges of its elytra.}
\boxed{The cutting edges are white.}
\boxed{The anthers of White Bear Sedge (Carex albursina) on the male inflorescence are yellow.}
\boxed{Yes. The larva of the mottled prominent (Macrurocampa marthesia) has a distinctive pale or whitish Y‑shaped marking on the top of its head.}
\boxed{The webbing between the toes of a Mute Swan (Cygnus olor) is black}
\boxed{Green}

\boxed{The Azure Tit’s feet are small, dark, and scaly in the typical passerine way, but they do not have any unusually patterned or visually distinctive scales—nothing beyond the normal, fine, non-ornamental scaling seen in most small songbirds.}
\boxed{No. In Sceloporus cyanogenys the dark neck banding is primarily dorsal/lateral and does not continue as a complete, continuous band across the ventral (throat) side of the neck.}

\boxed{No. In Aplocera plagiata the disruptive, bark‑mimicking pattern is on the forewings (and to a degree the hindwings). The abdomen, which is mostly covered when the moth is at rest, is comparatively plain—typically grey‑brown without the distinct white‑bark banding seen on the wings.}
\boxed{Yes. White-necked Herons have webbing between their toes, and the feet (including the webbing) are dark—typically black or very dark grey.}

\boxed{The tibiotarsus of the Social Flycatcher (Myiozetetes similis) is largely feathered, with feathers extending down over most of the tibiotarsus, leaving only the lower part (tarsus) unfeathered.}

\boxed{The developing / early flowering flame azalea (Rhododendron calendulaceum) flowers are not a uniform solid orange. Even in early stages the corolla typically shows noticeable color patterning—often with a yellow to golden blotch or flare on the upper (dorsal) petal and gradations or shading in the orange tone across the lobes, rather than a single, perfectly uniform orange color.}
\boxed{Yes. The underside of Anartia amathea’s wings is much duller and more faintly colored than the vivid, patterned upper side.}
\boxed{The anthers of sarsaparilla vine (Smilax pumila) are yellow.}
\boxed{In flight, the Ovenbird’s underwing shows a **distinctly spotted pattern**—dark spots on a lighter background across the underwing coverts.}
\boxed{The inside of a walleye’s mouth is typically white to pale pink in color.}
\boxed{The flight feathers of the Eastern Yellow Wagtail appear \textbf{blackish to dark brown (looking essentially black)} in flight, contrasting with the brighter body and wing coverts.}
\boxed{During flight, Couch’s Kingbird shows bright yellow underwing feathers.}
\boxed{The flowers of bush flax (Astelia fragrans) are small and star‑shaped}
\boxed{The matured legume of common milkpea (Galega officinalis) has a glabrous (smooth, hairless) surface texture.}
\boxed{The undertail coverts of a Golden-hooded Tanager appear white in frontal view while perching.}

\boxed{Yes. Male Prairie Lizards (Sceloporus consobrinus) can show bright, often blue and/or orange coloration on the throat and belly, which becomes especially vivid during the breeding season. Females and juveniles usually have much duller or absent belly coloration.}
\boxed{Yes. The California turret spider (Atypoides riversi) has conspicuous spines on its legs, especially on the front legs, which it uses for sensing and grasping prey at the burrow entrance.}
\boxed{The pistil tip is yellow.}

\boxed{When viewed closely, the throat of the Italian Wall Lizard (Podarcis siculus) is covered in small, **granular, fine scales** rather than large smooth plates or protruding thorns/spines. It appears finely textured or “grainy,” not thorny and not made up of broad, flat smooth scales.}

\boxed{No. The underside of the hindwings of the Western Painted Lady (Vanessa carye) does not show the same bold, eye-like dotted pattern seen on the upperside. Instead, the underside is more cryptic and mottled, with less distinct and less eye-like markings.}
\boxed{The inner surface of the mouth (oral cavity) of Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) is typically pale to whitish, often with a light pinkish tone rather than dark or black.}
\boxed{The anthers of Small-leaved kōwhai (Sophora microphylla) flowers are \textbf{purple}.}
\boxed{When swimming, the three-spined stickleback’s dorsal spines lie flat and are not conspicuously raised, so the dorsal fin appears low and streamlined along the back.}
\boxed{The ovary of the star flower (Lysimachia latifolia) appears green in close-up view.}
\boxed{The stems of *Psychotria nervosa* (Shiny-leaved Wild Coffee) are covered in fine pubescence, not a waxy coating.}
\boxed{The fruits of Indian Pink (Spigelia marilandica) are \textbf{capsules that are roughly egg-shaped to oval (ovoid)}.}
\boxed{The seeds of the common agapanthus (Agapanthus praecox) are black.}
\boxed{No. The flower buds of halberd‑leaved tearthumb (Persicaria arifolia) are typically bicolored rather than uniformly colored—for example, often pink with greenish tips.}
\boxed{The hindwings of the Cream-edged Dichomeris Moth are grey.}
\boxed{Yellow}
\boxed{The inflated fruit of hoary bowlesia (Bowlesia incana) has a surface covered with minute bumps (is finely tuberculate/roughened), rather than being smooth or distinctly ribbed.}
\boxed{Sergeant Baker (Latropiscis purpurissatus) do not have obvious, prominent external teeth; their teeth are small and not readily noticeable in typical views.}
\boxed{No. In Black-headed Heron (Ardea melanocephala), the primary flight feathers and the underwing coverts are both dark, so they do not show a strong contrasting color in flight.}
\boxed{The spines on the fruit of burro-weed (Ambrosia dumosa) are similar in color to the fruit surface, not distinctly different.}
\boxed{No. The inflorescence of bush arrowleaf (Pleurocoronis pluriseta) lacks ray florets and consists only of disc florets.}
\boxed{Yes. Matured seed pods of Broad-leaved Chervil (Chaerophyllum aromaticum) have clearly visible longitudinal ridges on their surface.}
\boxed{The ventral abdomen of \textit{Mangora acalypha} (Cricket-bat Orbweaver) shows a yellow background with a series of dark (blackish) spots arranged along the midline.}

\boxed{Yes. Early blue violet (Viola palmata) flowers have nectar guides—typically darker lines or shading on the petals (especially the lower petal) that visually guide pollinators toward the nectar and reproductive structures.}

\boxed{Yes. The Bath White’s upper wings are largely white with dark greenish‑black markings, while the undersides show a distinct greenish pattern on a yellowish‑white background, so the upper and lower surfaces differ noticeably in color hue.}
\boxed{Yes. The underside of the abdomen of the Mallow Scrub-Hairstreak (Strymon istapa) shows faint, fine longitudinal ridges/striations rather than being completely smooth.}
\boxed{The inside of the mouth of a black woodpecker (Dryocopus martius) is pink.}
